1. 
I  submit  for  your  approval  the  following  report  and  recommendation  on  (i)  a  proposed

II. 

RATIONALE: SECTOR PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES 

2. 
Enhanced  subregional  economic  cooperation  requires  improved  connections  across 
countries  and  between  centers  of  economic  activity.  Lao  PDR  is  pivotal  to  the  GMS  transport 
corridors  linking  northern  Thailand,  northern  Viet  Nam,  and  the  southern  provinces  of  the 
People’s Republic of China (PRC). Improving routes that connect provinces in Lao PDR to each 
other  and  to  borders  will  enhance  subregional  connections  between  northern  Lao  PDR  and 
surrounding countries. The GMS Transport Sector Strategy Study (TSSS)1 identified the Project 
as a high priority transport project that will link northern Lao PDR with Thailand. The feasibility 
study  for  the  Project  was  prepared  through  an  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  technical 
assistance (TA).2 The design and monitoring framework for the Project is in Appendix 1. 
 
A. 

Performance Indicators and Analysis 

3. 
Transport in Lao PDR is mostly by road, which carries about 70% of freight and 90% of 
passenger traffic. The main road transport network is fairly well-developed, except in the north 
where major gaps remain. The density of the road network is low, at about 0.14 kilometers (km) 
per  square  kilometer  (km2).  The  provincial  capital  of  Xaignabouri,  through  which  Route  4  (the 
project road) passes, is one of the two provincial capitals (of 17 total) without paved road access 
to the national road network. Only 14% of the road network is paved, including about half of the 
primary highways. The other roads have gravel or earth surfaces and most are barely passable 
during the wet season. Traffic on the national and provincial roads is generally light throughout 
the  country  because  of  population  densities  and  resulting  low  economic  activity.  Road 
maintenance needs to be improved, and issues of road safety and the integration of social and 
environmental  concerns  need  to  be  addressed  further.  Ongoing  transport  policy  initiatives 
address  the  following:  (i)  sustainability  of  the  transport  network,  (ii)  reduction  of  road  traffic 
accidents, and (iii) improvement of the capacity of road sector agencies to manage social and 
environmental impacts. The road subsector analysis is in Appendix 2. 
 
4. 
Road  Maintenance.    As  with  most  developing  countries,  Lao  PDR  has  not  provided 
sufficient financing for road maintenance. To address this issue, the Government established a 
Road  Maintenance  Fund  (RMF)  in  2001  to  provide  sustainable,  domestic  funding  for 
maintenance  of  the  national  road  network,  and  eventually  all  roads.  At  present,  10%  of  RMF 
revenues  is  allocated  to  the  local  road  network.  The  RMF  receives  income  from  domestic 
revenue  sources  as  well  as  from  international  sources  such  as  the  World  Bank,  Swedish 
International  Development  Cooperation  Agency  (Sida),  and  ADB.  Domestic  revenue  sources 
include  levies  on  gasoline  and  diesel  fuel,  heavy  vehicle  surcharges,  tolls,  and  international 
transit charges. Financial and capacity building support has been and continues to be given to

RMF  development  is  being  addressed  through changes  in government  regulations  and  policy, 
with the substantial assistance of international donor agencies led by the World Bank. 
 
Road Safety. Lao PDR has a poor road safety record. An ADB-financed study found that

traffic  accidents  cost  Lao  PDR  about  $47  million  per  year,  or  roughly  2.7%  of  gross  domestic 
product (GDP).6 The Government has recognized the need to improve road safety and reduce 
accidents  by  establishing  a  National  Road  Safety  Committee  chaired  by  the  deputy  prime 
minister  and  including  the  minister  of  communications,  transport,  posts,  and  construction;  the

culture;  and  the  director  general  of  the  Department  of  Transport  (DOT)  in  the  Ministry  of 
Communications, Transport, Posts, and Construction (MCTPC). The Road Safety Strategy and 
Action Plan (April 2005) has been prepared, and there have been decreases in accident rates 
during  2004  and  2005.  However,  it  is  expected  that  the  number  of  vehicles  will  increase  and 
road safety will require more attention. With the level of transit traffic (especially heavily loaded 
trucks)  increasing  under  the  GMS  agreements,  road  safety  awareness  and  enforcement  must 
be  increased  to  ensure  that  vehicle  and  truck  drivers  from  other  countries  are  aware  of  traffic 
rules and safety procedures in Lao PDR. The ADB-funded Roads for Rural Development Project 
(footnote  4)  includes  a  component  that  is  currently  assisting  with  the  implementation  of  key 
components of the National Road Safety Strategy.7 Under the ongoing project’s work plan, the 
project road will be included in its 2008–2010 program because it is a national road and a GMS 
road—both criteria for targeting resources to higher use and the thus higher risk roads.

B. 

Analysis of Key Problems and Opportunities 

1. 

Regional Cooperation 

One of the major impediments to building subregional economic cooperation is the poor

state  of  basic  infrastructure.  In  the  northern  GMS,  sections  of  key  transport  corridors  have 
already  been  developed  but  significant  gaps  remain.  There  is  a  need  to  improve  the 
connections between the provincial centers and the northern region of Lao PDR and to improve

8. 
Despite considerable progress over three decades of independence, Lao PDR remains 
one  of  the  poorest  countries  in  the  Asia  and  Pacific  region.  A  small  domestic  market,  the

major  focus  of  the  National  Growth  and  Poverty  Eradication  Strategy. 9 Substantial  external 
support has been devoted over the last 15 years to alleviating these problems by rehabilitating 
and modernizing the nation’s transport infrastructure, but additional assistance is necessary to 
improve the country’s transport network (para. 3).

4. 

Lessons  

13. 
The project design incorporates lessons from ADB’s loan and TA operations in general, 
ADB’s road subsector operations in Lao PDR, and other projects and TAs in the GMS. ADB has 
been a major financier of the main east-west and north-south economic corridors in Lao PDR, 
both  of  which  are  based  on  road  links.  ADB-financed  projects  in  the  transport  sector  have 
successfully contributed to providing access and communications, thereby helping to stimulate 
the economy and reduce isolation. The 2006 country assistance program evaluation (CAPE) for 
Lao  PDR13 found  that  ADB’s  assistance  to  the  transport  sector  in  Lao  PDR  was  efficient  and 
highly relevant, and had likely sustainability prospects and substantial institutional development 
and  other  effects.  The  CAPE  noted  that,  while  most  transport  projects  suffered  from  long 
implementation  delays,  these  had  been  substantially  reduced  under  the  most  recently 
completed  road  improvement  project.  The  CAPE  recommended  that  future  transport  sector 
projects  in  Lao  PDR  should  continue  to  support  road  maintenance  and  road  safety,  increase 
community  participation,  and  strengthen  MCTPC’s  capacity  and  awareness 
in  socio-
environmental  management.  One  lesson  learned  from  ADB’s  impact  evaluation  study  on  rural 
roads and poverty reduction14 is that the long-term benefits of road projects can be threatened 
by neglecting road maintenance. The Project is addressing the issue of implementation delays 
by  including  a  6-year  implementation  period  and  using  design-construct  contracts  for  the  civil 
works packages financed in part or whole by ADB. The Project includes specific components to 
address the road maintenance and road safety issues. Social and environmental concerns will 
be addressed through the project supervision consultants working closely with MCTPC staff to 
build on the experience gained through completed and ongoing road sector TAs and loans.

IV. 

PROJECT BENEFITS, IMPACTS, ASSUMPTIONS, AND RISKS 

A. 

Traffic Forecast 

39. 
Traffic  forecasts  by  vehicle  type  were  prepared  for  the  project  road  sections  for  2007–
2032 (Appendix 7). The forecasts are based on expected growth in GDP, income elasticities of 
demand, and analysis of regional trade and tourism patterns. Total traffic is forecast to grow at 
annual  rates  of  about  15.4–16.7%  during  2007–2017  (the  years  during  and  immediately 
following project implementation), except for the section including the bridge, which has higher 
growth.  The  high  growth  rates  during  2007–2017  are  due  in  large  part  to  the  development  of 
generated  traffic  following  project  completion.  International  traffic,  in  particular,  is  expected  to 
grow at a high rate during this period as the improved road allows for trucks and other vehicles 
to travel throughout the year. Total traffic is forecast to grow at annual rates of about 6.8–8.6% 
during 2017–2032. The projected growth rates are reasonable considering expected economic 
growth in the project area and experience in other ADB-financed road projects. Generated traffic 
arises  from  increased  shipments  of  agricultural  commodities  and  other  goods,  and  increased 
passenger traffic carrying tourists between Thailand and Louangphrabang. The improved road 
conditions will also generate demand by reducing vehicle operating costs (VOCs). Normal traffic 
is  expected  to  account  for  40–60%  of  total  traffic  on  the  project  road.  Generated  traffic 
comprises  35–43%  of  total  traffic.  Diverted  traffic  comprises  a  relatively  small  portion  of  total 
traffic at 5–20%. Motorcycles and small trucks (with fewer than three axles) comprise the largest 
portions of traffic on the project road, reflecting the economic status of residents of the project 
area and the importance to the economy of exports to Thailand. 
 
B. 

Economic Benefits 

40. 
The  economic  analysis  was  carried  out  for  the  Project  by  comparing  the  with-  and 
without-project scenarios (Appendix 8). In the without-project scenario, the road is assumed to 
remain  in  its  present  condition.  The  with-project  scenario  includes  routine  and  periodic 
maintenance according to international standards. The project preparatory technical assistance 
considered various mutually exclusive project alternatives such as different pavement types and 
alignments, and the proposed Project is based on the most cost-effective and least-cost option. 
Project  economic  costs  include  the  resource  costs  of  road  improvement  and  maintenance, 
equipment,  and  consulting  services.  The  primary  economic  benefits  for  the  Project  are  VOC 
savings,  time  savings,  diverted  traffic,  savings  from  improved  road  safety,  and  savings  from 
reduced  maintenance  costs.  Economic  benefits  were  calculated  using  the  same  methodology 
used  for  costs.  VOC  savings  will  accrue  primarily  from  improvements  in  the  road  surface, 
horizontal and vertical alignment, and increased average speed. VOC savings for normal traffic 
account for about 39% of total benefits while benefits from generated traffic account for about 
22%.  Generated  traffic  is  defined  as  new  traffic  induced  from  the  reduction  in  transport  costs 
arising from the Project, and includes both international and domestic generated traffic. Benefits 
for  generated  traffic  are  estimated  at  half  the  value  of  VOC  savings  for  normal  traffic.  The 

  

15

 

 

Project will result in improved average speeds along the project road, and the travel time for the 
entire  length  of  the  project  road  will  be  reduced  from  about  8  hours  to  about  5  hours.  Time 
savings  account  for  about  19.5%  of  total  benefits.  Benefits  from  improved  road  safety  and 
reduced  maintenance  costs  comprise  smaller  portions  of  total  benefits.  The  Project  will  also 
have other benefits, such as improved access to social services. However, these have not been 
quantified because of lack of sufficient data. 
 
41. 
The  EIRR  for  the  Project  is  16.6%,  and  the  net  present  value  is  $22.3  million,  using  a 
12% discount rate. Sensitivity analysis was carried out to test the effects of negative changes in 
the key parameters that determine the benefits and costs of the Project. The EIRRs calculated 
for  the  individual  sections  of  the  project  road  are  above  12%.  The  sensitivity  analysis  for  the 
Project indicates that capital costs would have to increase by 49% or total benefits decrease by 
32% for the EIRR to reach the level of 12%. Given ADB’s experience with similar projects in Lao 
PDR,  such  changes  are  not  expected  to  occur.  The  sensitivity  analysis  shows  that  the  EIRR 
exceeds 12% in all cases. A distribution analysis was carried out. The project benefits accruing 
to  Lao  PDR  are  distributed  among  five  groups:  (i)  users  of  freight  transport,  (ii)  users  of 
passenger transport, (iii) vehicle owners, (iv) labor, and (v) the Government and/or economy of 
Lao  PDR.  Users  of  passenger  transport  receive  about  25%  of  total  benefits,  users  of  freight 
transport  receive  about  19%,  vehicle  owners  receive  about  12%,  and  the  Government  and/or 
the economy receive about 42%.

E. 

Indigenous Peoples 

45. 
In the project area, 82.3% of the population is classified Lao-Tai (the main ethnic group); 
10.8% Mon-Khmer; 5.8% Hmong-Ewmian; and 0.3% Chinese-Tibetan. The indigenous peoples 
groups  have  been  relocated  to  the  project  area  since  1970  because  of  war  and  as  part  of 
government  relocation plans.  The groups  now  practice sedentary  agriculture  and rice  farming, 
and have been involved in commercialization of agriculture. Although they retain their traditional 
culture,  religion,  and  social  organization,  they  have  adopted  mainstream  language,  education, 
and  agricultural  practices.  The  literacy  rate  among  the  Mone-Khmer  is  close  to  the  national 
average but the Hmong-Ewmian have a literacy rate about half that of the national average. The 
village  consultation  indicates  that  indigenous  peoples  groups  support  the  road  improvement. 
Indigenous people account for 40% of the 255 households potentially affected by resettlement 
(para. 42). The impact on agricultural land is minor. These groups will benefit from the economic 
development arising from the Project, including improved access to markets and social services 
and  greater  opportunities  for  their  roadside  small  businesses.  Since  the  Project  will  have  no 
differential negative impact on indigenous peoples than on the main ethnic group, an indigenous 
peoples  development  plan  is  not  required.  To  maximize  benefits  to  indigenous  peoples  and 
ensure that they are not marginalized by resettlement activities, activities specific to indigenous 
peoples are included in the RP, gender strategy, and HIV/AIDS and human trafficking program.

1. 

Transport Planning and Coordination 

1. 
The  Ministry  of  Communications,  Transport,  Posts,  and  Construction  (MCTPC)  is 
responsible  for  the  development  of  national  and  provincial  roads,  civil  aviation,  urban 
development, telecommunications, river wharves, and river and road transport. Based on the five-
year  development  plans,  the  provinces  prepare  and  submit  annual  implementation  plans  for 
transport  projects  to  MCTPC,  which  submits  them  to  the  Committee  for  Planning  and 
Cooperation of the Prime Minister’s Office for approval. 
 
2. 
The  Department  of  Roads  (DOR)  within  MCTPC  is  responsible  for  the  administration, 
planning, construction, and maintenance of national roads. DOR monitors maintenance programs 
for  national  roads,  and  assists  the  provinces  with  the  implementation  and  monitoring  of  road 
improvement and maintenance programs of the local road network. Responsibility for execution 
of  all  routine  and  periodic  maintenance  has  been  delegated  to  the  provincial  Departments  of 
Communications,  Transport,  Posts,  and  Construction  (DCTPCs),  which  also  cover  district  and 
community/access roads. DCTPCs form the provincial arms of MCTPC and are responsible both 
to the central government through MCTPC and to the provincial administrations. DCTPC staff are 
appointed  partly  by  MCTPC  and  partly  by  the  provinces.  Within  the  road  subsector,  the 
responsibilities  of  DCTPCs  include  the  implementation  of  maintenance  of  national  roads  within 
each province; and full responsibility for construction, improvement, and maintenance of the local 
road network (provincial, district, and community roads). There are an average of 75 DCTPC staff 
in each province. 
 
3. 
There  are  168  permanent  staff  assigned  to  DOR—32  women  and  47  assigned  to 
externally financed projects. Of the eight divisions (including local roads) within DOR, the Road 
Administration Division is the main division dealing with road maintenance, and has responsibility 
for the certification of payments for disbursement from the Road Maintenance Fund for national 
road  maintenance.  There  are  16  permanent  staff  in  the  Road  Administration  Division.  The 
Planning  and  Technical  Division  has  16  staff  and  the  Project  Monitoring  Division  has  17  staff. 
Although staff numbers may vary between the divisions according to workload, the total number 
of divisions in DOR is not expected to change.  
 

2. 

Road Network 

4. 
Transport in the Lao People’s Democratic Republic (Lao PDR) is almost exclusively road-
based. Roads carry about 70% of freight and 90% of passenger traffic, so they are a key element 
of  the  basic  infrastructure  that  makes  up  the  enabling  environment  to  support  regional  and 
international  trade.  The  Mekong  River  and  its  tributaries  provide  river  transportation  (28%  of 
freight  traffic).  However,  only  1,300  kilometers  (km)  of  the  river,  which  flows  about  1,900  km 
through the country, are navigable owing to rapids and falls as well as low water levels during the 
dry  season.  Although  the  value  of  airfreight  is  negligible,  domestic  air  transport  plays  a  crucial 
role in establishing links between important urban areas and otherwise inaccessible parts of the 
country.  There  are  two  international  airports  at  Vientiane  and  Louangphrabang,  with  provincial 
airports for scheduled services at Pakse, Xiangkhouang, Louang-Namtha, Houayxay, Oudomxay, 
SamNua, and Phongsali, as well as other small airports and airfields throughout the country.  
 
 5. 
The  public  road  network  in  Lao  PDR  is  divided  into  several  different  classes  of  roads: 
(i) national,  (ii)  provincial,  (iii)  district,  (iv)  urban,  (v)  community  (rural),  and  (vi)  special.  Formal 
definitions of each class are given in the Road Law (03/NA/99), 1999. Definitions of national and 
provincial roads are given in Ministerial Decision 1312, issued in 1997, which formalized the list of 
national roads.1

Maintenance 

14. 
The objectives for road maintenance planning and institutional structures are founded in 
the recognition that funding allocation and service provision are separate functions with distinctly 
separate objectives. The objective for maintenance planning is to maximize the effectiveness of 
maintenance  expenditure  by  determining  the  level  of  service  and  maintenance  strategies  that 
optimize  the  benefits  to  the  nation  for  the  available  level  of  funding.  The  objective  for  service 
provision  is  to  implement  delivery  mechanisms  that  achieve  the  greatest  possible  efficiency  as 
measured by quality, performance specifications, and costs. 
 
15. 
A  sustainable  maintenance  regime  includes  (i)  an  institutional  structure  that  takes 
responsibility  for  funding,  planning,  and  implementing  maintenance,  while  separating  the 
institutions  responsible  for  funding  from  those  responsible  for  planning  and  management; 
(ii) consistent  and  adequate  yearly  funding  to  meet  a  level  of  service  (road  conditions)  that 
minimizes  total  transport  costs  for  the  nation;  (iii)  maintenance  planning  (such  as  the  Road 
Management System implemented under the World Bank supported-Road Maintenance Project 
[RMP])  with  the  road  inventory,  periodically  updated  condition  assessment,  traffic  volumes  and 
composition,  vehicle  operating  costs,  unit  costs  of  maintenance  operations  and  regional  cost 
variations,  and  population  served;  and  (iv) well-designed  maintenance  management  and 
implementation  delivered 
through  competitive  bidding  procedures  with  proper  contract 
documentation  and  performance  specifications,  adequate  supervision,  audit  and  quality  control, 
and capable and competitive contractors.

eventually all roads) from domestic sources. The RMF is based on the following principles:

Axle Load Control 

21. 
The maximum axle load set by MCTPC is 8.2 tons (Regulation 570/CTPC). In December 
1999,  the  Government  signed  the  Association  of  Southeast  Asian  Nations  (ASEAN)  Transit 
Traffic Agreement, in which maximum gross vehicle weights were set at about 9.1 ton axle load 
equivalent, with optional lower limits to be declared officially (e.g., during the wet season). Under 
the  World  Bank-funded  RMP  and  RMP2,  MCTPC  is  implementing  a  Heavy  Transport 
Management  Program,  whose  main  activities  comprise  review  of existing regulations,  enforcing 
regulations,  providing  equipment  (weigh  scales),  setting  up  41  weigh  stations,  and  training  and 
supporting a public information campaign. The program is complemented by earlier and ongoing 
ADB  project  components  (East-West  Corridor  Project  [footnote  4],  Northern  Economic  Corridor 
Project  [footnote  5],  and  Roads  for  Rural  Development  Project  [footnote  6])  for  the  supply  of 
equipment and establishing weigh stations.

Road Safety 

Road  accident  fatalities  continue  to  rise,  with  a  14%  increase  from  1999  to  2005.  Road 
22. 
accidents increased by 35% in the same period. With the current increase in vehicles, a growing 
population, and improved road network, the potential for even greater accident rates is high. The 
rate of fatalities in 2005 was 10 persons per 10,000 vehicles (414 fatalities), which dropped from 
19  persons  per  10,000  vehicles  in  1999  (362  fatalities).  The  rapid  increase  in  the  number  of 
motorcycles  has  increased  the  number  of  fatalities.  The  current  target  of  the  Department  of 
Transport  is  to  reduce  the  rate  of  fatalities  to  8  persons  per  10,000  vehicles  by  2010  and  5 
persons per 10,000 vehicles by 2015. A National Road Safety Strategy and Action Plan is being 
implemented  and  is  built  around  five  elements:  education,  enforcement,  technical  environment, 
coordination, and research and evaluation. The key issues in the strategy relate to (i) improved 
driving skills; (ii) use of crash helmets for motorcycle drivers; (iii) improved nighttime visibility for 
motorcyclists  and  cyclists;  (iv)  reduced  drunk  driving;  (v)  reduced  speeding;  (vi)  traffic 
management,  signing,  and  delineation  of  roads;  and  (vii)  use  of  seat  belts.  The  national  Road 
Safety  Strategy  and  Action  Plan,  which  received  prime  ministerial  approval  in  April  2005, 
envisages  implementation  through  a  National  Road  Safety  Council  currently  being  established 
under  MCTPC  and  the  forging  of  a  Road  Safety  Partnership  among  the  Traffic  Police 
Department,  Department  of  Transport,  and  Department  of  Education.

International  traffic,  in  particular,  is  expected  to  grow  at  a  high  rate  during  this  period  as  the 
improved road allows for trucks and other vehicles to travel throughout the year. Total traffic is 
forecast  to  grow  at  annual  rates  of  about  6.8–8.6%  during  2017–2032.  The  projected  growth

various  mutually  exclusive  project  alternatives,  such  as  different  pavement  types  and 
alignments, and the proposed Project is based on the most cost-effective and least-cost option. 
The economic analysis covers 25 years (2008–2032), based on a 6-year implementation period 
with most work being completed during the first 5 years. All benefits and costs are in constant 
2007 prices. The economic prices are expressed using the world price numeraire.

In the 2004 National Growth and Poverty Eradication Strategy (NGPES), the Government’s development goal is to exit

incorporated within the current Sixth Five Year Plan and Millennium Development goals. To meet the goals set for 
2020, rapid economic growth is being promoted to raise income levels. The Government has identified transport 
development as critical to achieving this development target. The NGPES has stated that the primary goal for 
transport is to “fully integrate the economy, thereby providing an enabling environment for trade and commerce and 
access for all Lao People to basic services”.a Poverty reduction is a key focus of the Government’s current and long-
term (2020) development plan. Road access is considered one of the keys to eradicating poverty in the Lao People’s 
Democratic Republic (Lao PDR) as discussed in the NGPES.  
 
The incidence of poverty nationally has reportedly declined from 46% in 1992 to just over 30% in 2005. The Laos 
Expenditure and Consumption Survey 2003 shows that both of the project provinces—Louangphrabang and 
Xaignabouri—have consumption and income levels above the national average. Provincial data indicates that 
Louangphrabang’s poverty incidence declined from 58.5% in 1993 to 40.8% in 1998 to 26.1% in 2004. Tourism and 
diversification and commercialization of agriculture have contributed to progress in poverty reduction in the project 
districts.   
  
By improving national and local roads, the Project will provide an enabling condition for poverty reduction through 
improved access to markets, employment, advanced education, and health facilities. Upgrading of an all-weather road 
will enhance benefits, enabling lower transport costs, and economic diversion through increased tourism, 
commercialization of agriculture, and development of other service industries in the project districts. Improved access 
to markets will open up opportunities for expansion of locally produced goods and services. Construction and 
operation of roads will provide significant opportunities for poor people to get employment and income from 
construction work. It is estimated that 8,130 person-months of work will be created during project implementation, of 
which 5,420 person-months will be unskilled.

B.  Poverty Analysis  
What type of poverty analysis is needed? 
 
The project area includes seven districts with a population of 311,000. Agriculture is the main source of employment in 
the project area. The project road passes through largely agricultural areas that are in transition from production for 
subsistence consumption and for local markets to more export-oriented commercial agriculture (maize, sesame, 
peanuts, mulberry fiber) and teak plantation. In addition to agriculture, other economic activities include small furniture 
factories, brick factories, saw mills, rice mills, noodle factories, drinking water factories, meat processing factories, ice 
factories, cross-border trade, small-scale river sand and gravel extraction, etc. 
 
Health data indicate that infant mortality has fallen because of a donor agency’s village health program, which ended 
in 2005. Coverage of immunization has increased. There are district level hospitals in Xaignabouri and  
Louangphrabang. Only a few villages have health centers and dispensaries. Access of the rural population to district 
hospitals is limited because of poor road conditions. Interviews with people in the project area indicate that respiratory 
health problems are common because of dusty road conditions. Pregnant women from rural communities face severe 
constraints receiving health services during pregnancy. 
 
Lao PDR has a relatively low incidence of HIV/AIDS (about 0.08%). The number of reported cases at the end of 2005 
was 1,827 with HIV and 432 with AIDS (60% male and 40% female). The most affected ages are between 20 and 
35 years old. Lao Red Cross had provided HIV/AIDS prevention education programs in each project district, supported 
by the World Health Organization and Cooperative for Assistance and Relief Everywhere (CARE). A provincial 
program that supports awareness of HIV/AIDS has been introduced in the project districts. Interviews with rural 
communities along the road indicate that relevant district staff have been visiting them every 3 months to discuss 
health issues.

Generally, one primary school serves two or three villages. Secondary schools are limited to the district towns or 
municipalities. All schools in 120 villages along the road reported to be understaffed and without essential resources. 
Interviews indicate that students attending secondary schools and living in boarding houses in town cannot visit their 
parents during weekends because of poor road conditions and lack of adequate public transport. Road conditions 
discourage many parents from sending their children to the district secondary schools.     
 
Impact of the Project. It is expected that the upgrading of Route 4 will provide a strategic all-weather link that will 
facilitate improved access to goods, markets, schools, medical facilities, and other social services for the project 
districts. The ability of the public sector to provide these services in a more cost-effective way could be increased 
because of improved access to the project road. The improved road condition will reduce dust pollution, which would 
have a positive health impact on people from 120 villages along the road. Road improvement will play an important 
role in reducing hazardous conditions for children walking several kilometers to school through very dusty roads. 
Increased access to transport in the project districts would increase enrollment of children from rural areas in the 
secondary schools in towns. Organization of local labor for the construction work for Route 4 and construction of the 
access roads will provide a source of income for men and women laborers from poor households. Engagement of 
local labor for road maintenance by the local government will provide seasonal employment for poor communities. 
 
Although improved transport facilities will bring positive benefits, the improvement of roads and the border crossing 
are likely to have some negative socioeconomic impacts for people living along the road. Certain vulnerabilities could 
be exacerbated by the increased accessibility, trade, and traffic. The ensuing economic development has the potential 
to increase inequalities within the communities by excluding some members from gaining these benefits because of 
lack of financial resources, skills, and knowledge. There will be some adverse impacts for people who are directly 
affected by resettlement. Potential socioeconomic impacts are (i) escalating land prices caused by the road 
improvements, concentration of landownership in the vicinity of the border, and potential displacement of local 
residents from the area; (ii) increased traffic risks for people living and working along the road caused by large 
volumes of traffic and higher vehicle speeds along the improved road; (iii) increased risks of exposure to HIV/AIDS 
and trafficking of women and children during construction activities and because of large volumes of transit traffic 
along the road and border area; (iv) increased flow of illegal drugs and number of drugs users in the project area as 
road improvements provide more favorable routes for drug dealers; and (iv) increased number of road accidents 
caused by increased traffic and vehicle speeds.  
 
The Project will include an HIV/AIDS awareness and prevention of human trafficking program in the construction 
camps, towns, and rural areas of the project districts. The awareness and prevention program includes: (i) advocacy 
actions on HIV/AIDS/sexually transmitted infections (STIs) and human trafficking prevention; (ii) information and 
education campaigns for all ethnic groups in respective sociocultural contexts; (iii) provision of HIV/AIDS and STI 
medical packages to clinics and medical centers along the road; (iv) developing community level contact persons for 
community mobilization on HIV/AIDS awareness, prevention of human trafficking, and community monitoring; (v) 
mobilization of existing poverty programs on agriculture and village development for poor households, with special 
focus on targeting indigenous peoples’ households to minimize their vulnerability and potential risk of human 
trafficking; and (v) developing project performance monitoring indicators on HIV/AIDS/STIs and human trafficking 
prevention by gender and ethnicity.  
 
The Project will include monitoring of social benefits, potential negative impacts, and indirect benefits. Disaggregated 
monitoring indicators by ethnic groups and gender will be used.

D.  Gender Development 

  
Strategy to maximize positive impacts on women: 
 
Situation of Women in the Project Area. Women in the project area suffer from gender biases, particularly in rural 
areas and among ethnic minorities. Women and girls are disadvantaged in terms of access to education and other 
social services. In the project area, women’s literacy is below that of men. Among the ethnic groups, women from 
Hmong indigenous peoples have a significantly lower literacy rate (39%) than men (57%). Women have less access to 
health care services in the project area—especially pregnant women who face constraints seeking health care from 
district hospitals during pregnancy because of poor road conditions. In recent years, a village-based primary health 
care program by nongovernment organizations (NGOs) and a bilateral agency has led to a reduction in child and 
maternal mortality in Xaignabouri Province. Women in the project districts play a major role in both subsistence and 
commercial agricultural activities. Despite the reduction of slash and burn agriculture, there is still widespread planting 
of dry rice and crops on slopes in the project area. Women carry a heavy burden in both subsistence and commercial 
agriculture. Women from indigenous peoples groups also play a critical role in collecting non-timber forest products. 
Agricultural extension services and other support mechanisms for many women from indigenous peoples are limited 
because they do not speak Lao. Men from indigenous peoples groups mainly have access to agricultural extension 
services. Women are entitled to inherit land titles but these are often not registered in the name of the woman because 
of (i) lack of knowledge of ownership rights, (ii) cultural reluctance on the part of women, (iii) lower levels of female 
literacy, or (iv) lack of awareness of the problem on the part of certifying officers. In the project districts, women play a 
leading role in retail trade, vending, guesthouses, and restaurants. Small and medium-sized enterprises are mostly 
owned by women, but poor infrastructure has been a problem for women’s enterprise in terms of capital and access to 
markets.  
 
Although Lao PDR has a relatively low incidence of HIV/AIDS, transmission of communicable diseases and HIV/AIDS 
may increase in the project area because of the influx of construction workers and transit traffic, including cross-border 
movements along the project road. Human trafficking is a serious issue in Lao PDR. A number of groups—including 
Lao Women’s Union, Ministry of Labor and Social Welfare, NGOs and donor agencies—are addressing trafficking 
issues, but data on the impact of the projects are sparse and more anecdotal than statistical. Construction and 
operation of the project road can increase the risk of human trafficking and HIV/AIDS/STIs for women and children. 
The Project includes an HIV/AIDS awareness and prevention of human trafficking program. The Project will provide a 
strategic all-weather link that will facilitate improved access to goods, markets, schools, medical facilities, and other 
social services by women. Interviews with women indicate that the improved road will provide them with access to 
local markets for agricultural products. The income and opportunities for women in roadside vending, food stalls, and 
small grocery stores will also be increased. There will be increased opportunities for women laborers in road 
construction work and road maintenance. The project districts have provisions for subcontracting local contractors for 
construction work, which would provide the opportunity to use local labor. The districts have a regular road 
maintenance program that is targeted at men and women from poor households. The gender strategy is to help 
women from affected households to secure access to compensation resources under the resettlement plan, to

A. 

Introduction 

This  summary  initial  environmental  examination  (SIEE)  report  has  been  prepared  to 
1. 
summarize  the  potential  environmental  impacts  of  the  proposed  Project,  which  has  been 
classified category B under the Asian Development Bank (ADB) categorization system. An initial 
environmental  examination  (IEE)  was  prepared  under  the  project  preparatory  technical 
assistance 1 (TA)  in  accordance  with  the  Environment  Policy  (2002)  and  Environmental 
Assessment Guidelines2 of ADB. The IEE was  prepared by the TA consultants and Ministry of 
Communications, Transport, Posts, and Construction (MCTPC) and has been approved by the 
Science, Technology and Environment Agency. 
 
B. 

Description of the Project 

2. 
The Project comprises (i) improvement of 367 km of the project road from Xiang Ngeun 
(the  junction  with  National  Route  13  near  Louangphrabang)  to  Nakha  (on  the  border  with 
Thailand), construction of a bridge over the Mekong River on the project road and improvement 
of about 100 km of rural access roads in the project area; (ii) procurement of equipment for use 
in operating the border post at Kenthao (now under construction) and for enforcement of axle-
load  controls  on  the  project  road;  (iii)  consulting  services  for  construction  supervision  and 
monitoring  and  evaluation  as  well  as  detailed  design  for  the  rural  access  roads;  (iv) 
maintenance of the national road network by financing periodic road maintenance subprojects; 
(v)  improvement  of  road  safety  by  financing  consulting  services  to  continue  the  ongoing  road 
safety  assistance  program;  and  (vi)  a  program  to  reduce  the  risks  of  HIV/AIDS  and  human 
trafficking  that  may  develop  during  the  rehabilitation  and  operation  of  the  project  road.  The 
project  road  (National  Highway  No.  4)  is  located  in  the  northern  Lao  People’s  Democratic 
Republic  (Lao  PDR),  linking  the  two  northern  provinces  of  Louangphrabang  and  Xaignabouri. 
The entire length of the project road (367 km) will be improved to a hard surface road (double 
bituminous  surface  treatment,  and  single  bituminous  surface  treatment  in  section  5).  The 
proposed alignment will generally follow the existing alignment, with some minor adjustments to 
provide  suitable  curves  and  improved  line-of-sight.  Drainage  will  be  improved  with  ditches. 
Improvement  of  the  project  road  will  also  involve  reconstruction  and  maintenance  of  bridges, 
and  construction  of  box  and  pipe  culverts.  The  Project  will  be  implemented  over  a  period  of 
about 6 years, including pre-construction activities.   
 
The road has been separated into the following five sections: section 1: junction of Road 
3. 
13 to Pakkhone (59.7 km); section 2: Tha Deua to Nam Pui (80.99 km); section 3: Nam Pui to 
Paklai (99.93 km); section 4: Paklai to Lao PDR-Thailand Border (65.54 km); and section 5: Lao 
PDR-Thailand Border to Nakha (62.32 km). The proposed project road will be class III and V (in 
section 5) with carriageway width between 4.5 meters (m) (in section 5) and 7.0 m with 1.0 m 
sealed  shoulders  and  formation  widths  of  between  8.5  (in  section  5)  and  12  m.  The  IEE 
boundaries for the road are, in general, 50 m on either side of a road centerline. For ecological 
impacts determination, it is extended to 1 km on either side of the road centerline. For air and 
noise impact prediction, it is extended to 50 m on either side of the road. The surface water IEE 
boundaries are 50 m downstream and 25 m upstream of any work site over the water.

C. 

Description of the Environment 

1. 

Physical Resources 

The climate in northern Lao PDR is subtropical and influenced by the annual southwest 
4. 
monsoon,  and  has  a  distinct  dry  and  rainy  season.  Dry  season  is  between  November  and 
March, and rainy season between April and October. During dry season, the weather cools and 
no rain may fall for several months. In the rainy season, the weather is hot with heavy rainfall. 
The two project provinces are considered mountainous areas. About 98% of the total land area 
of  Louangphrabang  and  about  70%  of  the  total  land  area  of  Xaignabouri  are  classified 
mountainous. Since the project road is in a rural setting and passes through small villages, and 
there  is  limited  industrial  development,  existing  air  quality  is  quite  good  with  the  exception  of 
total  particulate  matter  along  gravel  roads.  Noise  levels  are  relatively  low.  There  are  no 
significant wetland areas or ponds in the project area. 
 

2. 

Ecological Resources 

5. 
There  are  15  protected  areas  located  in  project  districts.  These  include  Nam  Pouy 
National  Biodiversity  Conservation  Area  (NBCA),  and  14  Provincial  Protected  Areas.  In  the 
vicinity  of  the  project  road,  the  forests  consist  mainly  of  planted  teak,  scrubs,  and  degraded 
secondary  forests  that  have  been  developed  into  agricultural  land  for  rice,  teak  plantations, 
gardening, and shifting cultivation. Undisturbed secondary forests are found far from the project 
road.  NBCA  is  not  anticipated  to  be  directly  affected  by  the  Project  since  rehabilitation  of  the 
project road is limited to the existing alignment, with some minor adjustments, and no additional 
road segments or new alignments are planned within the NBCA. The distance between the road 
alignment  and  NBCA  at  the  nearest  point  is  approximately  0.6  km.  Thus,  NBCA  including  its 
buffer zone will not be encroached upon by road widening and alignment adjustment activities. 
The  14  Provincial  Protected  Areas  are  located  farther  away  and  will  not  be  impacted  by  the 
Project. Presence of rare and endangered species in the project vicinity has not been reported. 
 

3. 

Economic Development 

Within the project area, there is a range of small- and medium-scale industrial activities. 
6. 
These include a number of furniture factories; agro-processing industries, including distilleries; 
meat  processing  plants;  drinking  water  factories;  and  other  factories  such  as  noodle  factories, 
ice  factories,  bakeries,  and  rice  mills.  Service  industries  include  print  shops,  TV/radio  repair, 
watch repair, and garages. Construction-related industries include sawmills, small brick factories, 
a  number  of  small  river-sand  and  gravel  extraction  operations,  and  rock  crushing  enterprises. 
Agriculture is the main source of income for local people. 
 
 
Louangphrabang  city  of  Louangphrabang  Province  is  the  most  important  tourism 
7. 
attraction  in  Lao  PDR,  and  has  been  a  World  Heritage  Site  since  1995.  Xaignabouri  Province 
has  little  tourism.  In  the  project  area,  a  number  of  tourism  sites—both  open  and  under 
development—are located near Route 4 and will have an increased number of visitors because 
of the road upgrading. 
  

4. 

Social and Cultural Resources 

Land acquisition for the Project will affect the assets of about 290 households along the 
8. 
road. The losses will include agricultural land, residential land, structures, trees, and crops. The

or archaeological sites will be affected by the Project. 
 
D. 

 
Forecasting Environmental Impacts and Mitigation Measures 

9. 
The Project is not anticipated to cause major adverse environmental impacts since it will 
mainly involve rehabilitation of the existing road alignment. The majority of the impacts identified 
will  be  experienced  during  the  construction  period,  so  they  are  largely  temporary  in  nature. 
Potential  impacts  include  soil  erosion  caused  by  earth  movement,  damage  to  agricultural  land 
as  a  result  of  improper  spoils  disposal,  loss  of  vegetation  and  habitat,  air  and  noise  pollution, 
water pollution, health and safety risks, and traffic disruption.   
 
The mitigation measures identified in the IEE’s environmental management plan (EMP) 
10. 
include (i) restoration of affected areas, e.g., borrow pits, after project completion; (ii) avoiding 
aggravation of soil erosion-prone areas; (iii) controlling sewage discharge and other waste fluids 
from  construction  sites,  and  hazardous  and  toxic  materials  from  bitumen  plants  and  from 
construction  equipment;  (iv)  maintaining  proper  drainage  to  avoid  stagnation  and  controlling 
downstream water pollution; (v) topsoil removal and reinstallation for revegetation on completion 
of  road  improvement  works;  (vi)  minimizing  noise,  dust,  emissions,  and  other  pollutants 
associated  with  civil  works;  and  (vii)  provision  of  adequate  road  access  during  construction. 
Detailed  information  on  environmental  impact  and  mitigation  measures  is  in  Supplementary 
Appendix  E.  The  civil  works  contractors  will  implement  these  mitigation  measures.  The 
supervision  consultant,  MCTPC  through  its  Environment  and  Social  Division  (ESD),  and 
concerned  government  environmental  agencies  will  monitor  their  implementation.  The  cost  for 
environmental  mitigation  measures  is  estimated  at  $666,100  and  the  cost  for  environmental 
monitoring and capacity development is about $137,600. 
  
11. 
The Nam Pouy NBCA is not anticipated to be directly affected by the Project, since road 
rehabilitation  is  limited  to  the  existing  alignment,  and  no  additional  road  segments  or  new 
alignment is planned within the NBCA. At the nearest point, the distance between the NBCA’s 
buffer zone and the road alignment is approximately 0.6 km. Thus the NBCA, including its buffer 
zone,  will  not  be  encroached  on  by  road  widening  and  alignment  adjustment  activities. 
Nonetheless, enforcement of wildlife regulations prohibiting illegal wildlife trade, especially trade 
in endangered species for the NBCA, will be strengthened under the Project. The strengthening 
will  be  implemented  by  the  NBCA  management  unit  through  a  checkpoint  operation  on  the 
project  road,  regular  patrolling,  and  a  wildlife  awareness  campaign  among  local  people.  The 
budget will be covered by the Project and is included in the environmental mitigation cost. 
 
12. 
Positive  impacts  that  may  be  attributed  to  the  Project  because  of  the  provision  of  a 
sealed all-weather road are (i) elimination of heavy road dust emission, thereby reducing safety 
risks  caused  by  extremely  poor  road  visibility;  (ii)  reduced  dust-associated  health  risks  to 
roadside  communities;  (iii)  improved  living  conditions;  (iv)  reduced  transport  costs;  and 
(v) increased economic growth in the project area and the region.   
 
Implementation  of  the  Project,  in  conjunction  with  other  Greater  Mekong  Subregion 
13.

cumulative impacts, over a longer time frame and beyond the project area: (i) an increase in air 
pollutants  and  greenhouse  gas  emissions;  (ii)  land  use  changes  caused  by  improved  access 
and economic growth; (iii) increased demand for and potential contamination of water resources; 
(iv) overall aesthetic transformation of the landscape; (v) changes in land values; (vi) improved 
health and sanitation conditions of residents because of better access; (vii) increased HIV/AIDS

G. 

Findings and Recommendations 

21. 
The  IEE  prepared  for  the  project  road  and  Mekong  River  bridge  crossing  provides  an 
assessment of potential impacts during various project phases. Mitigation measures to address 
such  impacts  are  contained  in  the  EMP,  which  can  be  adopted  by  any  co-financier  for  any 
portion  of  the  proposed  Project.  Based  on  findings  of  the  IEE,  the  potential  impacts  from  the 
Project are not considered significant. For various impacts identified during the construction and 
operation  phases,  corresponding  mitigation  measures  have  been  formulated.  Further,  impacts 
that might occur during the construction phase are considered temporary. The indirect impact to 
the  NBCA  in  the  operation  phase  is  considered  minor,  and  will  be  addressed  by  the  NBCA 
management unit with support from the Project. Proper implementation of the EMP will ensure 
minimal impacts to the environment.  
  
H. 

Conclusion 

Results  of  the  environmental  assessment  show  that,  with  proper  implementation  of  the 
22. 
EMP, the Northern GMS Transport Network Improvement Project will not cause adverse impacts 
to the environment. The IEE conducted for the Project is deemed sufficient and no additional or 
follow-up environmental study is recommended.
